newsitem.title: USA: U.S. crudes weaken into Sept pipeline nominations.
newsitem.headline: U.S. crudes weaken into Sept pipeline nominations.

text.p: U.S. crudes weakened broadly on outrights and domestic grades as demand slipped upon the completion of September pipeline nominations.
The reopening of three major Mexican crude export ports also accelerated the market's bearish downtrend, casting more pressure on the near-term market facing higher imports.
The Atlantic arbitrage opened the window to North Sea Gullfaks, Oseberg and even Russian Urals this week, which exerted weight on domestic October grades.
Oct West Texas Intermediate/Cushing was down 30 cents at $21.90-22.00, while the Sep/Oct roll held at 25-30 cents.
Late Friday afternoon, the remainder of September pipeline requirements were covered but in thin volume and lower prices.
September West Texas Intermediate/Midland fell to minus 20 cents under WTI, down from parity yesterday.
Light Louisiana Sweet/St. James was sold at minus 2 cents to WTI/Cushing, but the parcel was extremely small.
Heavy, sour prices pull backed more dramatically partly with the reopening of Mexican ports, especially Eugene Island.
West Texas Sour/Midland was heard done at minus $1.55 to WTI/Cushing, but Eugene Island dropped to minus $1.60, down from minus $1.25 traded mid-week.
Lacklustre margins and weaker gasoline prices are expected to rein in refinery demand.
Rumours of run cuts in the U.S. Gulf also kept buyers on the sides, although many were doubtful these were because of poor margins.
"I can't believe refiners will cut runs with stocks this low. It's probably turnarounds," an East Coast trader said, adding that people were trying to keep crude prices afloat.
